tool.name: Building_Extractor

param.name: lasdir
param.dialogReference: The directory where the LAS 1.4 tiles are located.

param.name: demdir
param.dialogReference: The directory where the bare earth Digital Elevation Model (DEM) tiles are located. These can be as Imagine .img, TIFF, ESRI Grid format. They should share the same naming convention as the LAS tiles.

param.name: outputdir
param.dialogReference: The directory where the output raster building objects will be placed.

param.name: spectral_detail
param.dialogReference: Sets the level of importance given to the spectral differences of features in the imagery. Valid values range from 1.0 to 20.0. A higher value is appropriate when the features are spectrally similar. Smaller values create smoother outputs. If the output scene is too generalized, then raise the value. If it is too segmented then lower the value.

param.name: spatial_detail
param.dialogReference: Sets the level of importance given to the proximity between features in the imagery. Valid values range from 1.0 to 20.0. A higher value is appropriate when the features are spatially interrelated. Smaller values create smoother outputs. If the output scene is too generalized, then raise the value. If it is too segmented then lower the value.

param.name: min_segment_size
param.dialogReference: The minimum size in grid cells that will be considered an object.

param.name: height
param.displayname: Minimum Height (As Measured in Elevation Units)
param.dialogReference: The minimum height of a grid cell in Z-values that is to be considered the roof height of a building. For example, with a value of 2 for elevation measured in meters, then any grid cell with a value less than 2 meters height will be turned to NoData.

param.name: lidarvalue
param.displayname: Data Attribute Used to Create DSM
param.dialogReference:
The LiDAR data attribute that will be used to create the Digital Surface Model (DSM). Being a DSM the Elevation attribute is the default.

  • ELEVATION (default) - Elevation from the LiDAR files will be used to create the DSM.

  • INTENSITY - Intensity information from the LiDAR files will be used to create the raster.

  • RGB - RGB values from the LiDAR points will be used to create 3-band imagery.

param.name: binningmethod
param.displayname: Sampling Method and Void Filling Method
param.expression: BINNING MINIMUM NONE | BINNING AVERAGE NONE | BINNING AVERAGE SIMPLE | BINNING AVERAGE LINEAR | BINNING AVERAGE NATURAL_NEIGHBOR | BINNING MINIMUM SIMPLE | BINNING MINIMUM LINEAR | BINNING MINIMUM NATURAL_NEIGHBOR | BINNING MAXIMUM NONE | BINNING MAXIMUM SIMPLE | BINNING MAXIMUM LINEAR | BINNING MAXIMUM NATURAL_NEIGHBOR | BINNING IDW NONE | BINNING IDW SIMPLE | BINNING IDW LINEAR | BINNING IDW NATURAL_NEIGHBOR | BINNING NEAREST NONE | BINNING NEAREST SIMPLE | BINNING NEAREST LINEAR | BINNING NEAREST NATURAL_NEIGHBOR
param.dialogReference:
The interpolation technique that will be used to determine the cell values of the output Digital Surface Model (DSM). The binning approach provides a Cell Assignment Method for determining each output cell using the points that fall within its extent, along with a Void Fill Method to determine the value of cells that do not contain any LAS points.

  • MINIMUM (default) - Assigns the minimum value found in the points within the cell.

  • AVERAGE - Assigns the average value of all points in the cell.

  • MAXIMUM - Assigns the maximum values found in the points within the cell.

  • IDW - Uses Inverse Distance Weighted interpolation to determine the cell value.

  • NEAREST - Uses Nearest Neighbor assignment to determine the cell value.

Void Fill Methods

  • NONE (default) - NoData is assigned to the cell.

  • SIMPLE - Averages the values from data cells immediately surrounding a NoData cell to eliminate small voids.

  • LINEAR - Trinagulates across void areas and uses linear interpolation on the triangulated value to determine the cell value.

  • NATURAL NEIGHBORS - Uses natural neighbor interpolation to determine the cell value.

param.name: rasterouttype
param.dialogReference:
The data type of the output Digital Surface Model (DSM).

  • FLOAT (default) - Output DSM will be a 32-bit floating point, which supports values ranging form -3.402823466e+38 to 3.402823466e+38. This preserves the original Z-value level of detail.

  • INT - Output DSM will use an appropriate integer bit depth. This option will round Z-values to the nearest whole number and write an integer to each raster cell value.

param.name: samplingtype
param.dialogReference:
Specifies the method used for interpreting the Sampling Value to define the resolution of the output Digital Surface Model (DSM).

  • CELLSIZE (default) - Defines the cell size of the output DSM.

  • OBSERVATIONS - Defines the number of cells that are to be used to determine the value of the grid cell.

param.name: samplingvalue
param.displayname: Grid Cell Spatial Resolution (As Measured in Horizontal Mapping Units)
param.dialogReference: Specifies the value used in conjunction with the Sampling Type to define the resolution of the output Digtial Surface Model (DSM). This is in map unit distance values. For example, a value of 1 for a data set defined in meters will create an output DSM spatial resolution of 1 meter.

tool.summary: This tool creates raster building objects using LiDAR LAS 1.4 tiles. The tool requires both the LAS and bare earth DEM tiles (as an Imagine .img, TIFF or ESRI Grid format) to be in separate folders and sharing the same naming convention. This tool takes these files and a user defined minimum height above ground for a building to create the raster objects.
